Award.AwardTitle: SEES Fellows: Leveraging the waterscape to increase agricultural landscape sustainability
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project is supported under the NSF Science, Engineering and Education for Sustainability Fellows (SEES Fellows) program, with the goal of helping to enable discoveries needed to inform actions that lead to environmental, energy and societal sustainability while creating the necessary workforce to address these challenges. Sustainability science is an emerging field that addresses the challenges of meeting human needs without harm to the environment, and without sacrificing the ability of future generations to meet their needs. A strong scientific workforce requires individuals educated and trained in interdisciplinary research and thinking, especially in the area of sustainability science. With the SEES Fellowship support, this project will enable a promising early career researcher to establish herself in an independent research career related to sustainability.

The Midwestern United States is often referred to as the Corn Belt for its importance as a center of agriculture. Unfortunately, agricultural productivity has come at the expense of the water quality and biological integrity of surrounding and downstream waterscapes within the Minnesota River Basin and the Northern Gulf of Mexico. This project will assess the ecological and economic implications of modifying wetland and backwater hydrologic connectivity to enhance nitrate retention during critical nitrogen loading storm events and seasons.

This project will develop a conceptual end-to-end framework to define functionality and variability of key hydro-biogeochemical processes controlling wetland nitrogen retention at multiple scales and to evaluate the economic-environmental trade-offs that define policy implementation feasibility. This research will contribute to scientific understanding of how hydro-biogeochemical processes at sub-watershed scales influence whole watershed export of an important aquatic contaminant, i.e. nitrate, by investigating the processes and scale specific controls in an intensively agricultural watershed. Defining sustainable agricultural practices and controlling diffuse pollutant loading with external environmental degradation are issues of local, national and global importance. By providing a sound scientific basis and an economic-environmental tradeoff assessment model, the proposed research could advance wetland policy implementation by addressing key knowledge gaps. The SEES Fellow, Dr. Amy Hansen, will work with host mentor Dr. Efi Foufoula-Georgiou at the University of Minnesota, and with partner mentor Dr. Catherine Kling at Iowa State University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding the complex physical, biological, and chemical connections between the waterscape and the landscape as well as the key scales which govern the strength of these connections is at the heart of determining sustainable solutions to environmental problems with spatially distributed origins. Specifically for this project, nitrogen from the intensively managed agricultural landscape of the Midwestern United States causes water quality impairments in rivers, lakes and streams at local, regional, and continental scales. By combining field observations, mathematical modeling and laboratory experiments, this project contributed new insights into watershed scale controls on nitrate removal via wetlands and other conservation practices in intensively managed agricultural landscapes. The results of this project advanced the science of agricultural sustainability by quantifying the dynamic relationship between wetland cover and nitrate reduction at a watershed scale and then placing that result within an economic-environmental cost-benefit framework such that wetland performance could be compared with in-field conservation practices which contributes towards our ability to assess policy implementation feasibility.

One major accomplishment of this project was to demonstrate the contribution of existing wetlands to nitrate reduction in intensively managed agricultural landscapes at a watershed scale. We took a multi-faceted approach to developing knowledge about wetland performance for nitrate reduction at a watershed scale sufficiently to compare performance to field based management actions. First, using field observation data we have shown that aquatic nitrate removal vial microbial denitrification depends on the availability of both dissolved organic carbon and nitrate and that the nitrate removal rate will be determined by whichever of these resources is more limiting. Second, by collecting observational water chemistry data from over 200 sites and seven sampling dates across a large watershed we decoupled the effect of agricultural inputs from wetland nitrate removal and quantified the effect of wetlands on nitrate concentration at a watershed scale. Third, we developed a watershed scale nitrate routing model that incorporated by hydrological and biogeochemical processes in order to characterize the streamflow conditions under which aquatic nitrate removal within wetlands and channels contributes measurable to reducing nitrate export or  under which hydrology will overwhelm aquatic nitrate removal potential. Together, this body of work quantitatively shows that wetlands are extremely effective at reducing nitrate concentrations and the conditions for which they should be designed to have the maximum effect on nitrate export. The progression of our work on this subject is published in a series of peer-reviewed papers, one in Nature Geosciences which was highly publicized through science news outlets, such as E&E News, EurekAlert!, Eurasia Review, Science Newsline, Phys.org. The results of this NSF funded research directly reached local and national public audiences through aired interviews with Minnesota Public Radio and with RFD-TV, an agricultural based national cable network station.  

The broader impacts of this study support policy makers, education and public engagement. This project contributed towards policy decision making by closing a knowledge gap about wetland performance through the development of key knowledge about wetland value as well as cost-benefit analysis allowing valuation in the context of other management options. The cost-benefit analyses provide insight into efficient solutions to promoting agricultural sustainability through a deepened understanding of the key characteristics of conservation action and gains in efficiency through effective placement. This project also promoted public engagement with the issue of agricultural sustainability and contributed towards broadening the STEM pipeline through the development of a high school curriculum piloted within the study basin and by mentoring five undergraduate students from five states through an REU program.
